teach.title: Learn: Describing People & "Be good at"
teach.intro: Describe appearance and personality, and say what someone is good at.
points: Appearance – curly hair: Amal has curly hair.
Appearance – short hair: My brother has short hair.
Appearance – tall: Fahad is tall.
Personality – shy: Ahmed is shy in class.
Personality – confident: Huda is confident on stage.
Personality – friendly: My teacher is friendly.
Pattern: Subject + be + good at + verb(-ing)
Examples: I'm good at drawing. She's good at singing. They're good at playing football.
teach.note: Smile, greet, then introduce your name and talent.

read.title: Reading: Back to School!
read.passage:
It's the first day of school after the long holiday. Amal and Fahad meet their friends in class. Everyone looks a bit different! Amal has short curly hair now, and Fahad is taller than last year.
Their teacher, Miss Salma, smiles and says, "Welcome back, everyone! This term we'll have a Talent Show, so start thinking about what you're good at!"
Amal says, "I'm good at drawing."
Fahad laughs, "I'm good at making people laugh — maybe I'll tell jokes on stage!"

practice.prompt: What event will happen this term?
Amal now has _______.
Who says "Welcome back, everyone"?
Amal is good at _______.
Fahad wants to _______.
"Be good at" means:
The opposite of "confident" is _______.
"She's friendly" — the adjective here is:
Which is correct?
Amal and Fahad are _______.
I brush my teeth _______ breakfast.
_______ I get home, I do my homework.
I play outside _______ I finish studying.

review.title: Review Tip
review.tip: Describe yourself: 3 appearance, 2 personality, 1 talent. Example: "I have short hair. I'm friendly and confident. I'm good at football."

teach.title: Learn: Comparative and Superlative Adjectives
teach.intro: Compare people and things using adjectives like tall, short, funny, beautiful, good.
points: Comparative (short adjectives): adjective + -er + than → Fahad is taller than Amal.
Comparative (long adjectives): more + adjective + than → This dance is more exciting than the other one.
Superlative (short adjectives): the + adjective + -est → Fahad is the funniest student.
Superlative (long adjectives): the most + adjective → That song is the most beautiful of all.
Irregular: good → better → best; bad → worse → worst
teach.note: Use -er + than to compare two; use the + -est (or the most) for three or more.

read.title: Reading: The Big Talent Show
read.passage:
It’s Talent Show Day! The hall is full of students and teachers. Amal stands on the stage with her drawings. Everyone claps — her art is beautiful!
Next, Fahad tells funny jokes. The audience laughs loudly. Then Salim dances — he’s faster than everyone else!
At the end, Miss Salma says, “All of you are winners! But Amal’s pictures are the most creative, and Fahad’s jokes are the funniest.”
Everyone cheers, and the students feel proud of their hard work.

practice.prompt: Where does the story take place?
What does Amal show on stage?
Who tells jokes?
Who dances?
The audience laughs because _______.
What does Miss Salma say about Amal’s pictures?
Which sentence uses the superlative form?
Which is the correct comparative sentence?
options: Amal is more taller than Rania.

practice.prompt: “Good → Better → Best” shows _______.
The students feel _______ at the end.
Amal is _______ (creative) than last year.
Fahad’s jokes are _______ (funny) than mine.
Salim is _______ (fast) dancer in the school.
This drawing is _______ (beautiful) than that one.

review.title: Review Tip
review.tip: Use -er + than for two; use the + -est (or the most) for three or more. Try: “My brother is taller than me. My sister is the kindest in our house.”

teach.title: Learn: used to / didn’t use to
teach.intro: We use used to + verb to talk about things that were true in the past but are not true now.
points: People used to write letters. (They don’t now.)
My grandfather used to walk to school. (Now students take the bus.)
Children used to play outside all day. (Now they play on tablets.)
Negative: didn’t use to → My dad didn’t use to have a mobile phone.
Question: Did you use to …? → Did you use to play football?
Tip: After “used to,” use the base verb. ✅ used to play ❌ used to playing

read.title: Reading: Life Before Screens
read.passage:
My grandmother always tells me stories about her childhood.
“We used to spend the whole afternoon outside,” she says.
“We used to climb trees, play hide and seek, and help our parents in the garden. We didn’t use to have televisions or tablets, so we made our own fun.”

I love hearing her stories. Life was slower but full of laughter.
Today, we have so many screens—phones, computers, TVs—but sometimes I think her life used to be happier and more peaceful.

practice.prompt: What did the grandmother use to do after school?
What didn’t they have in the past?
What does the writer think about the past?
People ____________ write letters to each other. (used to / didn’t use to)
Children ____________ play games on tablets. (used to / didn’t use to)
My dad ____________ have a mobile phone when he was young. (used to / didn’t use to)
My grandmother ____________ walk to school every day. (used to / didn’t use to)
Match the past activity with its modern version.
We _______ have a car when I was little.
Did you _______ go camping as a child?

review.title: Review Tip
review.tip: Write 3 sentences about how life was different when your parents were young using used to / didn’t use to.

teach.title: Learn: Past Simple (was / were / had / didn’t have)
teach.intro: Talk about life in the past using the past simple forms of be and have.
points: am/is → was: My grandfather was a farmer.
are → were: People were happy.
have → had: They had a big house.
don’t have → didn’t have: They didn’t have phones.
Use was/were to describe what something was like; use had/didn’t have to talk about possessions.
teach.note: Past time phrases: yesterday, last week, a long time ago, in the past, many years ago.

read.title: Reading: Life Long Ago
read.passage: Long ago, life was very different. People didn’t have computers or mobile phones. They wrote letters instead of emails, and they walked to school because there were no buses. Children played outside with simple toys. Families sat together every evening and talked. Life was quiet and simple — people had fewer things, but they spent more time together.

practice.prompt: What didn’t people have long ago?
What did people use instead of emails?
Why did children walk to school?
People had _______ things in the past.
What did families do every evening?
The opposite of “past” is _______.
Which sentence is correct?
“Life was quiet and simple” means _______.
Which time phrase fits? “People had no TV _______.”
The story is mostly about _______.
People _______ (not / have) cars in the past.
There _______ (be) many shops 100 years ago.
My grandmother _______ (have) a radio.
Children _______ (play) outside every day.

review.title: Review Tip
review.tip: Interview an older person and write 3–5 sentences using was, were, had, didn’t have.

teach.title: Learn: Technology (Past vs. Present) & "Could / Couldn't"
teach.intro: Compare old and modern technology and use could / couldn’t to talk about past ability.
points: Vocabulary: letter → email; telephone → mobile phone; computer → tablet; CD player → streaming app; typewriter → laptop.
We use could to talk about something possible in the past.
We use couldn’t to talk about something not possible in the past.
Structure: Subject + could / couldn’t + base verb.
Examples: My father could play the oud when he was young. My grandmother couldn’t use a computer.
teach.note: No "to" after could/couldn’t: say "could call", not "could to call".

read.title: Reading: Old and New Technology
read.passage: Fahad is working on a school project about technology. He shows his class two photos — one of an old black telephone, and one of a modern smartphone. He says, "In the past, people could call others, but they couldn’t send pictures or videos." Amal adds, "My grandmother used a typewriter. She could write letters, but she couldn’t save her work!" The students laugh and say, "Technology today is much faster and easier!"

practice.prompt: What is Fahad’s project about?
What two photos did Fahad show?
options: An old telephone and a smartphone
practice.answer: An old telephone and a smartphone

practice.prompt: What could people do in the past?
What couldn’t people do with old telephones?
What did Amal’s grandmother use?
Why did the students laugh?
options: Her grandmother couldn’t save her work
practice.answer: Her grandmother couldn’t save her work

practice.prompt: The word "faster" is a _______.
Which sentence is correct?
options: People could not to use telephones.

practice.prompt: The opposite of "old" is _______.
The main idea of the text is _______.
People _______ (could / couldn’t) use computers 50 years ago.
My grandmother _______ (could / couldn’t) use a typewriter.
We _______ (could / couldn’t) watch movies online before.
My father _______ (could / couldn’t) fix old radios.

review.title: Review Tip
review.tip: Use "could" for things possible in the past and "couldn’t" for things that were not possible. Write 3 sentences about what your parents could or couldn’t do as children.

teach.title: Learn: There was / There were + Past Simple
teach.intro: Talk about travel and places in the past vs. now using was/were and simple past verbs.
points: There was a small road. There were few cars.
People went by camel or boat. They didn’t travel quickly.
There weren’t buses in many towns.
Past time phrases: a long time ago, in the past, many years ago
teach.note: Use was for singular, were for plural. Negative: wasn’t / weren’t.

read.title: Reading: A Trip Long Ago
read.passage:
Many years ago, my grandfather went to the city by camel. The road was dusty and there were no buses. He took water and dates for the long journey. When he arrived, there was a small market and a well in the square. He wrote a letter to his family to say, “I am safe.”

Today, we drive on wide roads and arrive in a few hours. We send messages in seconds. Life is faster now, but I like hearing the stories of the past.

practice.prompt: How did the grandfather travel to the city?
What was the road like?
Were there buses long ago in the story?
What did the market look like?
How did he tell his family he was safe?
Which is correct?
Choose the past form of go:
Which sentence talks about the present?
options: We drive on wide roads now.
practice.answer: We drive on wide roads now.

practice.prompt: “There weren’t buses” means:
The main idea:
options: A long trip in the past vs. travel today
practice.answer: A long trip in the past vs. travel today

practice.prompt: There _______ a well in the square. (was / were)
There _______ buses long ago. (wasn’t / weren’t)
He _______ a letter to his family. (write → past)
People _______ quickly in the past. (travel → negative past)

review.title: Review Tip
review.tip: Make two sentences with there was/there were about your town long ago, and two sentences with past verbs (went, wrote, walked).

teach.title: Learn: Technology Vocabulary & “Could / Couldn’t”
teach.intro: Vocabulary for old and new inventions and how to talk about past ability.
points: Vocabulary (Old → New): Typewriter → Laptop; CD Player → Streaming App; Rotary Phone → Mobile Phone; Film Camera → Digital Camera; Radio → Podcast.
Could → ability in the past: People could type letters on a typewriter. My father could fix radios.
Couldn’t → impossibility in the past: People couldn’t send instant messages. Children couldn’t watch TV all day.
Structure: Subject + could / couldn’t + base verb.
No "to" after could/couldn’t: say "could send", not "could to send".
teach.note: Compare old and modern technology to see how life has changed.

read.title: Reading: From Old to New
read.passage:
Long ago, people could write letters, listen to the radio, and take black-and-white photos.
They couldn’t watch videos on YouTube, send emails, or play online games.
Today, technology is everywhere. We can type on laptops, take digital photos, and watch movies instantly.
Amal says, “Old inventions were important, but modern technology makes life easier and faster!”

practice.prompt: What could people do in the past?
What couldn’t people do long ago?
What can we do today?
What does Amal think about old inventions?
options: They were the same as now

practice.prompt: Modern technology makes life _______.
Which is correct?
What is the opposite of “old”?
Which sentence uses could?
“Typewriter → Laptop” shows _______.
The main idea of the text is _______.
Match the old invention with the new one.

review.title: Review Tip
review.tip: Use could / couldn’t for the past, and can / can’t for today. Write 3 sentences comparing old and new inventions (e.g., “People could write letters in the past, but now we can send emails.”). Try comparing 5 things at home: “My parents couldn’t play games on the phone. I can play games on my tablet.”

teach.title: Learn: Space Vocabulary & Asking Questions
teach.intro: Names of planets and space objects, and how to ask How…? questions using the present simple.
points: Vocabulary: Sun — The Sun is very hot.
Vocabulary: Moon — The Moon orbits the Earth.
Vocabulary: Earth — We live on Earth.
Vocabulary: Planet — Jupiter is the biggest planet.
Vocabulary: Star — Stars shine at night.
Vocabulary: Solar system — The solar system has eight planets.
Vocabulary: Telescope — We can see planets with a telescope.
Vocabulary: Comet — Halley’s comet appears every 76 years.
Vocabulary: Rocket — Rockets carry astronauts to space.
Vocabulary: Space station — The ISS is a space station orbiting Earth.
Vocabulary: Satellite — Satellites send information to Earth.
Vocabulary: Spacesuit — Astronauts wear a spacesuit in space.
How-questions: How far is the Moon from Earth?
How-questions: How many planets are in the solar system?
How-questions: How big is Jupiter?
Structure: How + adjective/adverb + verb + subject?
teach.note: Use present simple for facts about space: The Sun is a star. Saturn has rings.

read.title: Reading: A Trip Through Space
read.passage:
Amal dreams of becoming an astronaut. She looks at the night sky and counts the stars.
“How far is the Moon?” she asks. Her teacher answers, “About 384,000 km!”
Amal’s friend Fahad loves planets. He asks, “How many planets are there in the solar system?”
“There are eight planets,” says the teacher. “Each planet is different. Some are hot, some are cold. Some have rings, like Saturn.”
Amal imagines flying in a rocket to visit the planets and seeing the Earth from space.

practice.prompt: How many planets are in the solar system?
How far is the Moon from Earth?
Which planet has rings?
Amal dreams of becoming a _______.
Fahad asks about _______.
Which is a space object?
“Each planet is different” shows _______.
How does Amal feel about space?
Which sentence asks a question correctly?
What is Amal imagining?
Match the space object with its description.
right: Very hot star at the center of our solar system
Helps us see stars and planets

answers.Sun: Very hot star at the center of our solar system
answers.Telescope: Helps us see stars and planets

review.title: Review Tip
review.tip: Use How…? to ask about size, distance, or numbers in space. Write 3 sentences using the new words and a How…? question (e.g., “How big is Jupiter?” “The Moon orbits the Earth.” “Saturn has rings.”).

teach.title: Learn: Comparative Adjectives & Space Facts
teach.intro: Compare space objects with comparative adjectives and learn key ISS facts. Practice How…? questions.
points: Vocabulary: Astronaut — Astronauts live on the ISS.
Vocabulary: Space station — The ISS orbits the Earth.
Vocabulary: Microgravity — Astronauts experience microgravity in space.
Vocabulary: Rocket — Rockets take astronauts to the ISS.
Vocabulary: Module — The ISS has different modules for experiments.
Vocabulary: Orbit — The ISS orbits the Earth every 90 minutes.
Comparatives: bigger / smaller / hotter / colder / faster / slower.
Examples: Jupiter is bigger than Earth. Mercury is hotter than Pluto. The ISS moves faster than a plane.
Structure: Subject + is + comparative adjective + than + object.
How-questions: How many people are on the ISS? How fast does the ISS move?
teach.note: Use ‘than’ after comparative adjectives: bigger than, faster than.

read.title: Reading: Life on the ISS
read.passage:
Amal watches a video about the International Space Station. She sees astronauts floating in microgravity.
“The ISS is bigger than my school,” she says. “And it moves faster than a car!”
The astronauts live in small modules. They do experiments in space, eat special food, and sleep in sleeping bags.
Fahad asks, “How many people are on the ISS?”
“Usually six,” says the teacher. “Sometimes seven.”
Amal thinks life in space is amazing, but very different from life on Earth.

practice.prompt: How many people usually live on the ISS?
The ISS moves ______ than a car.
Compared to Earth, the ISS is ______.
What do astronauts do on the ISS?
What is microgravity?
Which module fact is correct?
options: The ISS has only one module

practice.prompt: How does Amal feel about space life?
Which comparative is used in the text?
The ISS orbits the Earth every ______.
Which question is correct?
options: How many astronauts is on the ISS?
How many people are on the ISS?
practice.answer: How many people are on the ISS?

practice.prompt: Match the object with the correct fact.
right: Does experiments and sleeps in sleeping bags

answers.Astronaut: Does experiments and sleeps in sleeping bags

review.title: Review Tip
review.tip: Use comparative adjectives to compare space objects: faster than, bigger than. Ask one How…? question about the ISS (e.g., “How fast does it orbit Earth?”).

teach.title: Learn: How to Ask for Information Politely
teach.intro: Today, we’re learning how to ask for information politely, especially when visiting museums, clubs, or interesting places.
points: Imagine you are exploring your city or a museum. You want to know: What time it opens; How much it costs; What you can see or do.
You can ask politely using these patterns.
Useful Phrases:
I’d like some information about… → I’d like some information about the National Museum, please.
Can you tell me…? → Can you tell me when the museum opens?
I’m interested in… → I’m interested in joining the Space Explorers Club.
How much is it? → How much is a ticket to the science exhibition?
Could you tell me…? → Could you tell me where the gift shop is?
Tip: Always start politely with please or could you, and don’t forget to say thank you afterwards.
Grammar Focus — Question Words: How, What, Where, When, Who.
Examples: How much is it? → Price | Where is the museum? → Location | What can I see there? → Activities or objects
teach.note: Be polite and clear: choose the right question word and use a polite opener.

read.title: Reading: A Visit to the National Museum
read.passage:
Amal and Fahad are visiting the National Museum. They want to know more about the exhibitions.
Amal asks the guide, “I’d like some information about the ancient artefacts, please.”
The guide smiles and says, “You can see them on the second floor. They show life from thousands of years ago.”
Fahad asks, “How much is the entrance ticket?”
“It’s fifteen rials,” replies the guide.
Amal notices a brochure and asks, “Can you tell me if there are special workshops for children?”
“Yes! We have a science club and a history workshop every weekend,” the guide answers.
Amal and Fahad are excited. Now they know what to explore first!

practice.prompt: What does Amal ask about first?
How much is the entrance ticket?
What does Fahad want to know?
Where are the artefacts located?
Which phrase is polite for asking information?
What workshops are available for children?
“Can you tell me…?” is used to ______.
Why are Amal and Fahad excited?
options: They know what to explore first
practice.answer: They know what to explore first

practice.prompt: Which question is correct?
“I’m interested in…” is used to express ______.
Match the question with the type of information.
left: I’m interested in joining the Space Club
Can you tell me about workshops?

practice.prompt: Write 3 polite questions to ask about a place you want to visit (use the Useful Phrases).

review.title: Review Tip
review.tip: Start politely (I’d like…, Can you tell me…, Could you…); use question words (How / What / Where / When / Who). Write 3 polite questions about a place you want to visit.

teach.title: 🧠 1️⃣ Learn Section: Talking About Big Numbers
teach.intro: Today, we’re traveling into space to learn how to talk about big numbers in English — just like scientists and astronauts do!
points: When we describe planets, distances, or stars, we often use thousands, millions, and billions.
🔹 Common Big Numbers
Number	How to Say It	Example
100	a hundred	There are about a hundred craters on the small moon.
500	five hundred	The rocket has five hundred parts!
1,000	a thousand	There are a thousand stars in this picture.
5,000	five thousand	The space station is five thousand kilograms in weight.
10,000	ten thousand	Ten thousand people visited the museum last year.
50,000	fifty thousand	The comet travels fifty thousand kilometres every hour.
100,000	a hundred thousand	A hundred thousand stars shine in this galaxy.
1,000,000	a million	The Sun is more than a million times bigger than Earth!
💡 Tip:
Don’t say “one thousands” ❌ — it’s one thousand ✅.
Add s only when the number is not exact (e.g., thousands of stars 🌟).

read.title: 🌌 2️⃣ Reading Passage: “Journey Through the Solar System”
read.passage:
The Solar System is full of wonders and big numbers!
The Sun is at the center, and eight planets move around it.
The Earth is about 150 million kilometres away from the Sun.
Jupiter, the biggest planet, is more than 1,300 times larger than Earth.
A day on Venus is 243 Earth days long — that’s a very long day!
Scientists use telescopes and satellites to study millions of stars, comets, and asteroids every year.
The numbers may be big, but they help us understand the universe better!

practice.prompt: How many planets are in the Solar System?
How far is Earth from the Sun?
Which planet is the biggest?
How long is one day on Venus?
What do scientists use to study stars and planets?
“A hundred thousand stars” means:
What does “the biggest” mean?
Which word is used to describe many but not exact large numbers?
Why are big numbers important in space?
options: They help measure and understand distances
practice.answer: They help measure and understand distances

practice.prompt: “150 million kilometres” is a way to talk about:
Match the number to its correct phrase:

🗣️ Imagine you’re a space explorer! Write three sentences using big numbers.
Example:

My rocket can travel five thousand kilometres.

The galaxy has millions of stars.

The telescope can see a hundred thousand planets.

review.title: 💬 4️⃣ Review Tip
review.tip:
✅ Use hundred, thousand, million for big numbers.
✅ Don’t add “s” after an exact number.
✅ Remember: thousands of = many, but not exact.
✅ Always use commas to separate big numbers (1,000 not 1000).

teach.title: 1️⃣ Learn Section: Discovering Museums Around the World
teach.intro:
Museums are windows to the past, present, and future. They tell stories through objects, paintings, fossils, and inventions.
Each museum is special — some show art, some show science, and others show history.

Let’s learn how to talk about museums and describe what we can see or do there.
points: 🔹 Vocabulary You Need
Word | Meaning | Example
Exhibit | something shown in a museum | There’s a new dinosaur exhibit.
Ancient | very old, from long ago | Ancient statues tell stories of history.
Display | to show something | The museum displays old coins and books.
Guide | a person who shows you around | The guide explained the history of the castle.
Gallery | a room or building for art | We saw a famous painting in the art gallery.
Collection | a group of objects | The museum has a large collection of fossils.
Artifact | an object from the past | This artifact is from Ancient Egypt.
Entrance | the way into a place | The entrance is near the big blue gate.
teach.note:
💡 Tip:
When you talk about museums, use “There is / There are” and “You can see…”

Examples:

There are many interesting exhibits in the museum.

You can see beautiful paintings and old coins.

read.title: 2️⃣ Reading Passage: “A Trip Around the World’s Museums”
read.passage:
People all around the world love visiting museums.
In France, the Louvre Museum has the famous painting Mona Lisa.
In Egypt, the Grand Egyptian Museum shows ancient treasures and mummies.
In Oman, the National Museum in Muscat displays Omani history, culture, and traditional crafts.
In America, the Smithsonian Museum has space rockets and dinosaur skeletons!

When you visit a museum, you learn about art, science, and history.
You can ask questions, read information, and explore different sections.
Museums help us understand how people lived long ago — and how we live today.

practice.prompt: Which painting is in the Louvre Museum?
Where is the Grand Egyptian Museum?
What can you see in the Smithsonian Museum?
What does the National Museum in Oman display?
Why do people visit museums?
The Louvre Museum is in _______.
What is the meaning of “artifact”?
options: An old object from the past
practice.answer: An old object from the past

practice.prompt: Which word means “a person who shows visitors around”?
What can you learn in a museum?
“The museum displays ancient treasures.” What does displays mean?
Match the museum to its country:

🗣️ Write 4 sentences about a museum you know.
Use There is / There are / You can see / I’d like to visit…

Example:

There is a big museum in Muscat.

You can see old swords and jewelry.

There are many beautiful photos of Oman.

I’d like to visit the National Museum again!

review.title: 4️⃣ Review Tip
review.tip:
✅ Use There is / There are to describe what’s in a museum.
✅ Remember: museum = a place to learn about history, art, or science.
✅ Be polite when asking for information — “Could you tell me where the gallery is?”
✅ Museums are not boring… they are full of stories waiting to be explored! 🌟

teach.title: 1️⃣ Learn Section: Let's Go Shopping!
teach.intro:
Oman has many types of shops — from modern malls to traditional souqs (markets) filled with beautiful local products.
You can buy dates, frankincense, silver jewelry, clothes, toys, and electronics — everything you need!

When shopping, we must use polite English to ask for prices or help.
Let's learn how to talk about shops and money the right way.
points: 🏪 Types of Shops
Shop | What You Can Buy | Example Sentence
Butcher's | meat | I went to the butcher's to buy beef.
Greengrocer's | fruits and vegetables | The greengrocer's has fresh dates and tomatoes.
Pharmacy | medicine | You can buy medicine at the pharmacy.
Fishmonger's | fish | The fishmonger's sells fresh kingfish.
Gift shop | presents and souvenirs | We bought frankincense from the gift shop.
Toy shop | toys and games | My brother bought a puzzle from the toy shop.
Jeweller's | gold, silver | The jeweller's has Omani silver khanjars.
Corner shop | small food items | I got milk and bread from the corner shop.
💰 Money & Prices Vocabulary
Word | Meaning | Example
Wallet / Purse | where you keep your money | I keep my rials in my wallet.
Save | to keep money for later | I save my pocket money to buy books.
Spend | to use money | I spend three rials on snacks.
Buy / Sell | to get or give items for money | They buy and sell dates at the souq.
Pocket money | money you get weekly | I get pocket money from my parents every Friday.
🔹 Useful Phrases for Shopping
• How much is it? → How much is this khanjar, please?
• It's five rials. → It's fifteen rials for the necklace.
• I'd like to buy... → I'd like to buy a box of Omani halwa.
• Can I help you? → Yes, I'm looking for a souvenir.
• Thank you very much! → You're welcome!
teach.note: 💡 Tip: Always use please and thank you when shopping. Being polite shows respect and makes shopping more enjoyable for everyone!

read.title: 2️⃣ Reading Passage: A Visit to Muttrah Souq
read.passage:
Amal and her family went to Muttrah Souq in Muscat. The air smelled of frankincense and perfume.
There were small shops selling silver jewelry, colorful scarves, and Omani sweets.
Amal asked politely, "How much is this scarf, please?"
The shopkeeper smiled and said, "It's three rials."
She looked at another one and said, "I'd like to buy this blue scarf."
Her father bought Omani halwa and a small silver khanjar as a gift for his friend.
At the end, they thanked the shopkeeper and left happily with their bags full of Omani treasures.

practice.prompt: Where did Amal and her family go?
What did the shop sell?
How much was the scarf?
What did Amal's father buy?

teach.title: 🛍️ Let's Explore Shops & Prices!
teach.intro:
Welcome to the world of shopping! 🌟

From the grand Mall of Oman with its glass ceiling and luxury stores, to the cozy traditional souqs filled with the smell of frankincense and spices — Oman has it all!

Today, we'll learn how to talk about different shops, ask for prices in rials, and use the right words when shopping.

Ready to become a smart shopper? Let's go! 🛒✨
points: 🏬 Where Do We Shop in Oman?
🏛️ Modern Malls → Grand places with many stores — like Mall of Oman, Muscat Grand Mall, and Oman Avenues Mall. You can find clothes, electronics, toys, food courts, and even cinemas!

🕌 Traditional Souqs → Historic markets like Muttrah Souq and Nizwa Souq where you can buy spices, silver jewelry, Omani halwa, frankincense, textiles, and handmade crafts. Shopkeepers are friendly and you can often bargain politely!
🏪 Corner Shops → Small neighborhood stores for quick items like milk, bread, snacks, and drinks.
🏪 Types of Shops
Shop | What You Buy | Example Sentence
Butcher's | meat (beef, chicken, lamb) | I buy meat at the butcher's.
Greengrocer's | fruits & vegetables | We buy mangoes at the greengrocer's.
Pharmacy | medicine | I get medicine from the pharmacy.
Toy shop | toys | My brother loves going to the toy shop.
Sports shop | balls, shoes | I bought a football from the sports shop.
Gift shop | souvenirs | Tourists buy frankincense in the gift shop.
Corner shop | snacks & drinks | I buy milk from the corner shop.
Fishmonger's | fresh fish | The fishmonger's sells kingfish.
💰 Money & Prices
Word | Meaning | Example
Rials (OMR) | Omani currency | The toy costs five rials.
Baisa | coins (1000 baisa = 1 rial) | It's 2 rials and 500 baisa.
Price | how much something costs | What's the price of this shirt?
Receipt | proof of payment | Can I have a receipt, please?
Bargain | ask for lower price | Can you make it eight rials?
Change | money returned | Here's your change: 2 rials.
⚖️ Grammar Focus: Countable vs. Uncountable Nouns
🔹 Countable Nouns (you can count them):
• We use: a, an, one, two, three, many, few
• Examples: a toy, an apple, three oranges, five rials
• Sentences:
✅ I want a bottle of water.
✅ We need some eggs.
✅ I'd like an orange, please.
🔹 Uncountable Nouns (you CANNOT count them):
• We use: some, any, much, little
• Examples: water, rice, money, medicine, frankincense, milk
• Sentences:
✅ Do you have any rice?
✅ I need some medicine.
✅ How much money do you have?
�️ Pronunciation Tip:
Say the 's ending clearly: butcher's (butcher + s), greengrocer's — it means "the shop of that person."
🌍 Culture Connection: Omani Markets
In Oman, people visit souqs like Muttrah Souq or Nizwa Souq. You can buy silver, spices, and frankincense there. Shopkeepers are friendly, and you can often bargain politely!
💬 Useful Shopping Phrases:
• How much is it? → How much is this football, please?
• It's ___ rials. → It's ten rials.
• I'd like to buy... → I'd like to buy a box of halwa.
• Can I help you? → Yes, I'm looking for a souvenir.
• Can you make it less? → Can you make it eight rials? (bargaining)
• Thank you very much! → You're welcome!
teach.note: 🎯 Quick Tip: Emphasize the 's in shop names (butcher's, toy shop's). Always use 'please' and 'thank you' when shopping. In souqs, polite bargaining is part of Omani culture — but always smile! 😊

read.title: 📖 Reading: A Day at the Mall & Souq
read.passage:
Amal and Fahad had a busy shopping day in Muscat!

First, they visited the Mall of Oman. The building was huge with a beautiful glass ceiling. They went to the toy shop.
"How much is this teddy bear?" asked Amal.
"It's eight rials," said the shopkeeper.
Fahad bought a football from the sports shop for twelve rials.

Later, they visited Muttrah Souq with their parents. The narrow streets smelled of frankincense and spices. Their mother bought some Omani halwa from a gift shop.
"How much is this box?" she asked.
"It's five rials, but for you, four rials," the kind shopkeeper said with a smile.

At the end of the day, they stopped at a corner shop near home and bought milk, juice, and some chocolate.

Amal said, "I love shopping in Oman — we have modern malls and traditional souqs. Both are amazing!"

Fahad agreed. "And everyone is so polite and kind!"

review.tip:

✅ How to ask prices politely: "How much is it?" / "It's ___ rials."

✅ Countable vs. Uncountable:
   • Countable: a toy, an apple, three eggs

✅ Omani shopping culture: Modern malls + traditional souqs = the best of both worlds! 🇴🇲

💡 Remember: Good manners make you a better shopper. Always say please, thank you, and smile! 😊

teach.title: 💰 Learn — Money, Prices & Budgets
teach.intro:
Imagine you've got 10 rials and you're visiting Muttrah Souq. You want a scarf, some halwa and a postcard. Can you buy everything and still save some money?

Today we learn how to ask prices, count money, and make smart choices like a real Omani shopper! 🛍️
points: � Money Words
Word | Meaning | Example
Rials | Omani currency | I have 10 rials in my wallet.
Baisa | small coins (1000 baisa = 1 rial) | It costs 2 rials and 500 baisa.
Wallet | where you keep money | My wallet is in my pocket.
Purse | bag for money (usually for women) | She keeps her rials in her purse.
Pocket money | money given weekly by parents | I get 5 rials pocket money every Friday.
Price | how much something costs | What's the price of this scarf?
Cost | another word for price | How much does this cost?
Change | money returned when you pay more | Here's your change: 2 rials.
🗣️ Useful Phrases
• How much is it, please?
• It's three rials.
• How much does this cost?
• I'd like to buy…
• Do you have change for five rials?
⚖️ Grammar Focus — have to / don't have to
✅ have to = It's NECESSARY (you must do it)
• I have to save money for school books.
• You have to ask politely for the price.
• We have to pay before leaving the shop.
❌ don't have to = It's NOT necessary (you can choose)
• You don't have to buy everything now.
• I don't have to buy the bracelet today.
• We don't have to spend all our money.
💬 Mini-Modelled Examples
Conversation at the souq:
🧕 Shopkeeper: "That scarf is 3 rials."
👦 Customer: "How much is the bracelet, please?"
🧕 Shopkeeper: "It's 15 rials."
👦 Student self-talk: "I have 10 rials. I don't have to buy the bracelet today."
teach.note: 💡 Budget Tip: A budget means planning how much money you'll spend and save. Smart shoppers always keep some money for later!

She asks politely, "How much is this scarf, please?"

The shopkeeper smiles and says, "It's three rials."

Amal thinks, "I have to save some money for school." She buys the postcard and the halwa and leaves two rials in her wallet.

She is happy because she spent her money carefully.

review.title: 🎯 Review & Teacher Notes
review.tip:
� Quick Recap:

✅ Vocabulary: rials, baisa, wallet, save, spend, pocket money, price, cost, change

✅ Polite phrases: "How much is it, please?" / "I'd like to buy…" / "Do you have change for…?"

👩‍🏫 Teacher Suggestions:
• Use real coins or printed rials for hands-on practice

🎮 Game Idea — "Souq Saver":
A fun, timed shopping game where students:
• Are given a budget (e.g., 10 rials)
• Must buy required items from a shopping list

• Make smart choices to stay within budget
• Get bonus points for using polite phrases
• Learn to give correct change

Game teaches vocabulary, polite phrases, and arithmetic while making budgeting fun! 🛒✨

💡 Assessment: Quick quiz on vocabulary + budget calculations
📌 Extension: Ask students to create a savings plan for a 20-rial toy based on weekly pocket money

lessons.title: The World of the Corner Shop

teach.title: Teach Section – Understanding Corner Shops
teach.intro: In Oman, corner shops are part of daily life. They’re small, friendly stores in many neighborhoods — perfect for buying snacks, drinks, or things you forgot from the supermarket. Let’s learn how to describe a corner shop, talk about prices, and use polite English when buying or selling.
points: 🏪 Vocabulary – Shops & Shopping
Word | Meaning | Example Sentence
Corner shop | A small local shop | The corner shop near my house sells cold drinks.
Kiosk | A small stand that sells newspapers or snacks | There’s a kiosk near the bus stop.
Save | Keep money for later | I save my pocket money every week.
Spend | Use money to buy things | I spend my money on toys.
Wallet | A small case for keeping money | My father keeps his rials in a brown wallet.
🗣️ Useful Phrases for Everyday English
Can I help you?
How much does this cost?
That’s two rials, please.
Would you like a bag?
Have a nice day!
⚖️ Grammar Focus: Have to / Don’t Have to
We use have to for things that are necessary: I have to go to the shop before dinner.
We use don’t have to when something isn’t necessary: You don’t have to buy milk, we already have some.
teach.note: 🌍 Omani Culture: Corner shops often sell Omani halwa, incense, and fresh dates near the counter. It’s polite to greet the shopkeeper with ‘As-salamu alaykum’ and say ‘Shukran’ when you leave.

teach.title: What Are Good Manners?
teach.intro: Good manners are ways we show respect and kindness to others. Every culture has its own special ways to greet, thank, and speak politely. In Oman, we greet people by saying ‘As-salamu alaykum’, and we show respect by speaking kindly, helping others, and waiting our turn. In other countries, people may show good manners differently — by shaking hands, bowing, or smiling.
points: 🔹 Vocabulary – Politeness Around the World
Word / Phrase | Meaning | Example
Polite | Showing good manners | It’s polite to say ‘please’ and ‘thank you.’
Greet | Say hello to someone | Omanis greet with ‘As-salamu alaykum.’
Bow | Bend slightly to show respect | In Japan, people bow to greet each other.
Respect | Care and kindness for others | We respect our teachers and elders.
Share | Give part of something to others | I share my lunch with my friends.
⚖️ Grammar Focus – Using ‘should’ for Advice
We use should to give advice or talk about what’s right.
You should say thank you.
You shouldn’t be rude to your friends.
We should help people in need.
🔹 Culture Focus – Manners by Country
Country | Manners
Oman 🇴🇲 | Say ‘As-salamu alaykum’, show respect to elders, remove shoes in homes.
Japan 🇯🇵 | People bow when they meet, and they don’t talk loudly in public.
India 🇮🇳 | People greet with ‘Namaste’ and show respect to teachers.
UK 🇬🇧 | People say ‘Please’ and ‘Thank you’ often and queue politely.
USA 🇺🇸 | People smile and say ‘Hi!’ or ‘Nice to meet you!’
teach.note: Optional video: Kids Learn Manners Around the World (YouTube)
